title: How to Perform an Eskimo (Inuit) Kiss, or “Kunik”

steps.title: Get close to your partner.
steps.content: Get close to your partner. You will need to be very close so that your faces can touch. This is a fun way to show affection if you are already close to one another, like if you are cuddling on the couch or holding each other close.

steps.title: Touch noses.
steps.content: Touch noses. Touch the tip of your nose to the tip of your partner's nose. You can leave your eyes open or closed; do whichever feels more comfortable.

steps.title: Shake your head from side to side as if you're saying "No.
steps.content: Shake your head from side to side as if you're saying "No. " Go back and forth a few times as you rub noses - that's an Eskimo kiss! If you're feeling very affectionate and cuddly, move forward and nuzzle your nose into your partner's cheek.

steps.title: Approach your partner.
steps.content: Approach your partner. A kunik is an affectionate greeting between people who know each other intimately, such as family members or romantic partners. It's not done instead of kissing, and in fact is not meant to be romantic at all. In some cultures, it is only done between mothers and children. [1] X Research source You will need to stand very close to your partner. If you are a mother sharing a kunik with your child, you may want to pick him or her up or squat down to his or her level.

steps.title: Nuzzle your partner's face with your nose.
steps.content: Nuzzle your partner's face with your nose. The nose, cheeks, and forehead are all common spots to nuzzle. [2] X Research source Imagine you partner is wrapped up tight against the cold, probably wearing a hood and a scarf. You would rub your nose over the skin that is still exposed and not bundled up.

steps.title: Inhale, suctioning your partner's skin against your nose and upper lip.
steps.content: Inhale, suctioning your partner's skin against your nose and upper lip. [3] X Research source Rediscovering your loved one's smell is an intimate, loving way to reconnect and strengthen your bond. It is possible this type of greeting dates back to when language was not very evolved, and we relied more on our senses--like smell--to identify, communicate, and connect with others.
